content.markdown:
## Trilogy Studio Demo Dashboard

[Trilogy Studio](https://github.com/trilogy-data/trilogy-studio-core) a SQL-ish-centric analytics tool based on a custom SQL variant - [Trilogy](https://trilogydata.dev/). Trilogy can be used standalone, but the Studio is similar to mashup of Bigquery Studio and Looker Studio - or Redash - and is designed to make exploring, modeling, and presenting data easy. Trilogy centralizes semantic and modeling in the language layer, making it perfect for data consumption work with fast feedback and iteration loops, composability, and reuse.  

This dashboard is based on a demo model (the common TPC-H dataset) and runs using DuckDB WASM in your browser. Dashboards should work well on desktop or mobile, though drilldown is not supported on mobile. If you want to play around with more interesting data, the 'share & explore' option on the sidebar has a list of public datasets you can import from BigQuery, DuckDB, and Snowflake. (the [satellite dashboard](https://trilogydata.dev/trilogy-studio-core/#screen=dashboard-import&import=https%3A%2F%2Ftrilogy-data.github.io%2Ftrilogy-public-models%2Fstudio%2Fgcat_space.json&dashboard=satellite_dashboard&modelName=gcat_space&connection=duckdb) is a fun different view). You can also directly query data through the 'editors' on the top left of the left-hand nav. 

Note: This dashboard is in view mode by default; click the mode dropdown in the top right to change to edit or fullscreen. We'd recommend staying in view mode to scan the dashboard, then trying to edit. Feel free to destroy the dashboard - it's local to you. 

But first, some charts: we're looking at {order_id_count} orders from customers in {order_customer_nation_id_count} countries, ordering parts from suppliers in {part_supplier_nation_id_count} nations. Each of these views is a simple SQL query + some lightweight chart configuration - and they can all freely cross-filter and interact. We'll explains some features as you scroll down. 

We'll start with some basic headline metrics and a bar chart.

1.content:
# Selecting total revenue
# Total revenue is based on the extended price minus discount
select 
    local.total_revenue,
    sum(quantity) as total_items_sold,
    count(order.id) as total_orders,
    count(order.customer.id) as total_customers  ;
1.name: Headline Metrics

5.content:
SELECT
    part.type,
    total_revenue,
    avg(discount) as avg_discount
HAVING
    total_revenue > 0

ORDER BY
    total_revenue desc
LIMIT 15
;
5.name: Top 15 Parts By Sales

6.content:
# This query selects the count of local.id 
# for each country, representing items sold to each country. 

select 
    order.customer.nation.name, 
    sum(quantity) as items_sold 
having 
    items_sold > 0;
6.name: Sales By Country

7.content:
# Query to get total sales by supplier 
# Total sales is calculated as the extended price minus discount

select 
    part.supplier.nation.name, 
    count(part.supplier.id) as nation_supplier_count,
    total_revenue
having total_revenue > 0 
order by
    total_revenue desc
;
7.name: Supplier Info

8.content:
select 
    order.customer.nation.region.id as region_id,
    order.customer.nation.region.name,
    count(order.id) as order_count,
    sum(order.total_price) as total_sales 
where 
    order.customer.nation.region.id is not null;
8.name: Regional Sales

9.content:
select
  order.date.month_start,
  part.supplier.nation.name,
  sum(local.revenue) as monthly_revenue;
9.name: Revenue Trends

content.markdown:
# Filtering
You can click on one of the countries above to filter by suppliers located in it. Try shift-clicking to select a few. (currently selected: {part_supplier_id_count} suppliers, {nation_count} countries.) Click on chart background to clear. You can also add more traditional filters, like these widgets to the right/bottom (if you're on mobile). There's a global dashboard filter bar at top too, which is most useful if you have an LLM hooked up. 

On the time chart below, you can do a classic click-drag to filter to a range.

### Basic Filters

Are currently quite basic; date support/multi-select and others should come soon.

# Drilldowns

Ctrl-click to drill down into a value, which will let you select any drilldown value to split the chart by after filtering to the selected value. Try drilling down in any of the charts. Drilldowns can be infinitely nested. 

You can revert a drilldown through a button available on the right on mouse-over, which will return the chart to an original view. Drilldowns are also available when just running queries in the IDE.

# Configuring Charts

The studio attempts to pick the right visual by default. For example, a field that is a lat/long or a country name in the select will default to a map view. How to display fields is inferred up from "traits" associated in the semantic model. Trilogy handles appropriately passing these traits through transformations and clients can optionally consume these, as the Studio does. You can further customize the visuals - the perfect visual can't always be inferred - but if you can fix the display by fixing the model, that's the best for reuse. 

```trilogy
import std.geography; # access the country type
property id.name string::country; # capitalized; eg UNITED STATES or FRANCE or CANADA
```
